content: How can I help you today?

Well, honestly, I’m here because my wife pushed me to come. Things have been really tough at home, and I guess I just don’t know what else to do. I’m not really sure how this works or if it’ll even help.

It's understandable to feel unsure in this situation, especially when things are challenging at home. It's great that you're open to having this conversation, even if you're not sure yet how it might help. What’s been going on for you at home that's made things tough?

My son has been having a lot of behavioral issues. He’s been acting out, and it’s been really hard on my wife and me. We’re trying to figure out how to help him, but it feels like we’re failing, and it’s putting a huge strain on our marriage. It’s like we’re all disconnected.

That sounds really heavy—trying to support your son while feeling disconnected from your wife and struggling to make things better. It must be tough balancing all of that. What has this experience been like for you emotionally?

It’s been overwhelming, honestly. I feel like I’m drowning most days, like no matter what I do, it’s not enough. I’m worried all the time about my son, but I miss my wife and daughter too—it feels like I’m failing everyone.

It sounds like you're carrying so much right now—concern for your son, longing for connection with your wife and daughter, and a fear of not being enough for everyone. That must be exhausting. What’s helped you manage those feelings, even just a little, on the toughest days?

Honestly, not much helps. I just try to get through the day, but it all feels like a blur. Sometimes I just shut down or zone out because it feels like there’s no way to fix any of it. Even the things I used to enjoy just don’t seem to do anything anymore.

It sounds like you're feeling stuck and worn down, with little relief from the things you used to enjoy. Zoning out might be the only way you’ve found to cope when it all feels overwhelming. It’s clear how much you care about your family and want things to get better. What do you think has made those enjoyable things feel less meaningful to you lately?

If I’m being honest, it’s hard to enjoy anything when my mind is always racing with worries about my son, my wife, and everything else. I feel like I can’t fully relax or be present anymore—like I should be doing something to fix things, even though I don’t know what that is.

It sounds like you're feeling trapped in this cycle of worry—where even relaxing feels impossible because your mind keeps pulling you toward fixing things, even when the solutions don’t seem clear. That sounds exhausting and frustrating. What would it mean for you to have even a small moment to feel present or at ease?

Honestly, I can’t even imagine what that would feel like right now. It’s been so long since I’ve had that kind of peace. Maybe it would feel like I could finally breathe again, you know? But I just don’t know how to get there.

It sounds like peace and ease feel distant for you right now, and yet, having that space to breathe would mean so much. You’ve taken a step here by opening up about how you're feeling and what you’re going through. What do you think might make it easier to move even a little closer to that sense of relief?

I honestly don’t even know. I feel like I’ve tried everything I can think of, and nothing seems to work. I guess that’s why I’m here, but I’m still not sure what I’m supposed to do or if this will even help.

It sounds like you’ve been doing your best to try different things, even when solutions feel unclear or out of reach. That kind of effort takes strength, especially when you’re feeling overwhelmed. Being here could be an opportunity to explore what might help you move forward, but it’s okay not to have all the answers yet. What would you want to focus on most during our time together?

I guess I’d want to figure out how to help my son and fix things with my wife. I don’t want to lose my family, but I feel so stuck and don’t know where to even start. Maybe just a first step to not feel like I’m failing all the time.

It’s clear how much you care about your family and how deeply you want things to improve. Feeling stuck and unsure where to begin sounds incredibly tough, but looking for even a small step forward is a meaningful place to start. What do you hope things could look like for you and your family if things felt more connected and less overwhelming?

If I could imagine it, I’d just want us to feel happy again—like we’re a team, supporting each other instead of feeling distant. I’d love to see my son doing better and for my wife and me to feel close again, like we’re in this together. I just want to feel like I’m being a good dad and husband, and not failing the people I love.

You have a clear and heartfelt vision for your family—to feel connected, like a strong and supportive team, and to be the father and husband you strive to be. That goal says a lot about how much you care and want to make things better. What do you think might be one small step toward building that sense of connection—whether with your son, your wife, or the family as a whole?

Wanting that connection shows so much about your commitment to your family. Maybe creating one moment—just a small shared activity or conversation with your wife or kids—could be a good start. What’s something simple you all used to enjoy together?

We used to take walks together as a family. It was nice to just be outside and talk, but we haven’t done that in ages. Everyone’s been so busy or upset that we don’t even think about things like that anymore.
